title: 112_s3218
content:
The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 is the short title of the Act. It includes a table of contents outlining the sections, with Title I focusing on improved coordination of export promotion programs. TITLE I--IMPROVED COORDINATION OF EXPORT PROMOTION PROGRAMS
- Consolidation of duplicative export promotion activities
- Clarification of roles of Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee members
- Inclusion of State agency representatives on Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee
- Reporting to Congress on Committee activities
- Enhancements to Export.gov for export information
- Development of a single window for export control compliance information

TITLE II--FACILITATION OF EXPORT OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES Sec. 201-206 outline various initiatives to promote exporting and support small businesses in export activities. Sec. 101 focuses on consolidating export promotion activities and providing information on trade missions and fairs. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include identifying opportunities for consolidating offices, coordinating electronic databases, and providing detailed listings of trade activities. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include providing detailed listings of current and future Federal and State-led trade missions, trade fairs, and related activities for better service delivery to US businesses. The Secretary of Commerce will make this information available on Export.gov or a successor website. SEC. 102. CLARIFICATION OF ROLES OF MEMBERS OF TRADE PROMOTION COORDINATING COMMITTEE. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of each department or agency that is a member of the TPCC in export promotion and financing activities. This includes identifying and explaining the role of the department or agency, describing goals and objectives, and providing rationale for measuring and reporting on those goals and objectives. Congress is also included in paragraph (5) as part of the reporting process. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of TPCC members in export promotion. This includes incorporating recommendations from the Comptroller General and updating references to the United States Travel Association. SEC. 103 amends the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 to include a representative of state agencies on the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. SEC. 104 requires reports to Congress on the activities of the TPCC. Section 2312(f) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to require the chairperson of the TPCC to submit an annual report to Congress by March 30. The report should include details on the strategic plan, its implementation, revisions, funding for export promotion activities, and the interagency working groups on energy. Additionally, the inspector general of the Department of Commerce is also required to submit reports to Congress. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce prepares and submits an annual report to Congress by March 30 on the TPCC's successful duties and implementation of the strategic plan. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce consults with other federal agencies in preparing the annual report for Congress on the TPCC's activities. The term 'appropriate congressional committees' refers to specific Senate and House committees. The appropriate congressional committees consulted by the Inspector General of the Department of Commerce include Senate committees on Small Business and Entrepreneurship, Appropriations, Energy and Commerce, Financial Services, Foreign Affairs, and House committees on Appropriations, Energy and Commerce, Financial Services, Foreign Affairs, Small Business, and Ways and Means. SEC. 105. REPORT ON IMPROVEMENTS TO EXPORT.GOV AS A SINGLE WINDOW FOR EXPORT INFORMATION. The Director of International Trade of the Small Business Administration will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment, with recommendations for enhancing Export.gov as a comprehensive resource for exporting information and a single platform for submitting required export information. Entities specified for the exportation of articles from the United States include small business concerns that are exporters, the President's Export Council, State agencies, district export councils, and trade associations. SEC. 106. REPORT ON DEVELOPING A SINGLE WINDOW FOR INFORMATION ABOUT EXPORT CONTROL COMPLIANCE. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration must submit a report to congressional committees within 180 days of this Act's enactment, evaluating the benefits of creating a website as a comprehensive resource for export control laws and a single platform for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific Senate and House committees. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration must submit a report to specific Senate and House committees within 180 days, evaluating the benefits of creating a website as a comprehensive resource for export control laws and a single platform for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. The committees include the Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship of the Senate, and the Committee on Energy and Commerce and the Committee on Small Business of the House of Representatives. TITLE II--FACILITATION OF EXPORT OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES

SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS.

    In this title--
            (1) the terms ``Administration'' and ``Administrator'' refer to the Small Business Administration and its Administrator;
            (2) the term ``region of the Administration'' is defined in section 3(u) of the Small Business Act;
            (3) the term ``small business concern'' is defined in section 3 of the Small Business Act.

SEC. 202. PROMOTION OF EXPORTING.

    Section 22(c)(11) of the Small Business Act is amended to include conducting outreach events in each State promoting exporting for small businesses. The Administrator will establish a pilot program for matchmaking events between small businesses and foreign buyers. At least one event per region will be held annually, and events may be coordinated with outreach events. The program authority will end on September 30, 2015. Additionally, there will be export control education under Section 204. SEC. 204 amends the Small Business Act to prioritize educating small businesses on Federal export control regulations. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing to enhance Federal export finance programs for small businesses and coordinate government assistance for small businesses seeking to export. SEC. 206 ensures the availability of State resource guides on export.gov. SEC. 206 mandates the Secretary of Commerce to provide State resource guides on Export.gov, detailing export promotion and financing resources by State.
